Bottle bought at Schneider br√§uhaus in Munich. A hazy golden beer with a big white head. The aroma is of bananas, spices, lemon and hops. The taste is light banana, spicy and hoppy. Medium to full body with a light bitter dry finish, quit good!

500ml bottle.  Nicely spicy, fruity aroma, lightly sweet and estery with notes of lemon, banana, fresh, leafy hops, faint clove and doughy yeast, along with some lightly honeyed apple in the background.  Cloudy dark golden color with a lasting, foamy head.  Flavor profile is a nice combination of malty sweetness, grainy wheat, citrus, peppery spice, and substantial hop bitterness, with some faint alcohol towards the finish, which is long, gently acidic and warming.  Lingering clove, leafy hop flavor and phenols.  Fluffy, dry, well-carbonated palate with a medium-full body.  Possesses some mild complexity and a good depth of flavor.  Recommended.

My brother and I enjoyed this in the bierhaus in Munich.  The color out of the bottle was a nice golden color until the sediment became involved.  Then, it was a gloriously murky mess of brownish gold, with a white head which dissipated to nice thickness and just stayed.  The aroma was all citrus, bitterness, and earth.  The flavor was earthy to te point of nearly seeming dirty.  The citrusy hops cut through everything, complimenting the yeast and lemony wheat.  The piney undertone was almost forgotten with the powerful citrus and even more powerful bitterness taking full control.  This was a standout beer in my beer pilgrimmage to Germany and Brussels, not because it was the best, but because it was unique to the trip.  This one will not be easily forgotten.  Might have to get my bro to send me some more if he can find it.

Deep, hazy gold. Sticky, off-white head settles pretty quickly to a solid half inch, and stays through the pint, leaving nice lacing.

Banana ester is quite strong in this bottle, with a hearty kick of clove. It does not make a pleasant combination with the abundant, somewhat aggressive hops. Sweet malt enters the mix, and does not help the situation.

On the thin side of medium in the mouth. The hops and spicy wheat are in control here, though the clove makes itself known in the long finish. Good slightly sweet malt in there as well. A bit hot to boot. Definitely tastes better than it smells.

Carbonation is appropriate for a weizen, with the abundant bubbles doing a fine palate-scrubbing job here.

Full points for originality here, but I just don¬ít like this. It¬ís virtually undrinkable for me.

500ml bottle-pours a big off white head and cloudy deep orange color.  Aroma is creamy banana, apricot citrus-grapefruit and lemon zest-(cascade/Amarillo also?) hops, wheat.  Taste is alcohol, fruit, musty and clove.  Taste not up to the aroma, but nicer and does follow.  Some hops.  Dry finish.  Good effervescence.

Bottle. Pours cloudy gold with stupendous ivory head, great lacing, and lots of bubbles. The aroma is very refreshing with lots of hops, fresh flowers, a little zest, and some yeasty spice. The flavor is floral hops right off, then some honey and spicy wheat tones. There is some yeastiness, but it is overshadowed by the crispness of the hops. The finish is slightly malty, but in a dry way. The aftertaste is slightly spicy alcohol and a lingering slight dryness. This is very tasty, indeed.

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of MoritzF. Pours a very hazy golden with a handsome, dense, off-white head leving a pretty lacework. Fresh - somewhat herbal - hoppy nose. The usual banana flavours are very downplayed - almost non-existing. Medium body, dry malt accents and again these herbal and citrusy accents with a distinct and atypical bitterness. Very interesting. 041007
This was just great.  Mostly resembled a wheat beer, with banana flavors and aromas, but with a spicy hop character blending extremely well.

I am not a hophead by any stretch of the imagination. But I am an American. And as an American who loves well-made Belgian and German beers, I have to say that more European beers could do some mighty things with a reasonably hoppy kick in the ass. Here I¬ím thinking about the Chouffe Houblon. And of course I¬ím thinking about this beer. Predictably, I loved it.My brother and I drank ours at the bierhaus in Munich. It poured a thick, muddy, grayish-brown, with massive amounts of yeast swirling around like smoke. Smells like hops, evergreen, and lemon zest. Covering the booze is no problem with those tangy yet grassy hops. The bitterness is in the driver¬ís seat, and you¬íre in the back with the lemon and pine. The citrus stands out to me, because I think there¬ís a marriage of the citrus in the hops and the citrus in the weisse yeast. This beer floored me on the first go-round, and I¬ím glad they let me buy a few to go.
Friggin¬í awesome beer.  Bottles, at Circa, 9/28/07.  Like a big, meaty, chewy weiss with no noticeable sourness and pleasant hopping that doesn¬ít overpower.  So awesome.
Bottle. Very interesting beer. Pours a hazy amber. Nose of bananas and pine. The wheat and hops both come through strong in the flavor. Really good. Very enjoyable.

Hmmm... this beer was definitely interesting.  Just the uniqueness alone made it worthwhile.  But then you had the awesome wiessebier aromas with bananas and bubblegum and a whole load of stickly sweet hops on top of that.  The taste was remniscent of Aventinus, but with a dimension of it¬ís own.  There were too many spices and complexities to even point out.  But on top of all of that it was so easily drinkable, so very refreshing, that I just wanted another...

(bottle) Cloudy, murky amber colour with a huge light-beige foamy head. Sweet, light wheat-malty, fruit-accented lemon aroma with very aromatic piney hops and phenolic spice. Moderately wheaty, lemony fruity taste with a piney hops character from the beginning and present phenolic spices; dry, almost astringent bitter finish with a very pleasant piney hops character and a lemon-fruity, hoppy aftertaste with balanced spicy, slightly clovy phenols Extraordinary and unusual Weizenbock with a distinctive hop bite. I really hope there is more to come from the Saphir hops..
Bottle at √òLbaren (Thanks to Lars). Unclear yellow - white head. High high hoppy, soapy, elderflowers, wheat, sweetness, bitterness, mild smooth body. Not that good, but interesting to try !!!

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2009 Bottle (thanks to joss and the Schneider brewery!) Golden, cloudy, big very persistent fluffy white head; very strong piney-hoppy nose with a spicy phenolic touch; full sweet-bitter flavour, medium to full bodied; long lasting fruitiness in the full piney-aromatic bitter-sweet finish. Wow ! The best of all beers of the Weizen-family.........

Murky, deep amber appearance with a large, off white head, spotty lacing and a good deal of sediment.  Crisp fruit aroma, spicy, with an herbal edge.  Esters play a suporting, rather than dominating, role typical for this style.  Taste is earthy, slightly tart, bitter, with plenty of spicy hops playing off the absorbant wheat flavors. Full-to-medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel leading  to a long lasting finish.

50 cl bottle via trade with jasonmech77 - Pours a hazy amber color with a large white head.  Light lacing.  Has a spicey ester (apple & banana) aroma.  Flavor is also fruity with just a touch of malt.  Medium body.  Fairly smooth palate.  A nice, easy drinking beer.  Thanks Jason.

Bottle Pours a hazy orange with a thick white head.  Aromas of clove and slight banana.  I had hoped for more hops.  Flavor is unique starts off like a typical weizen and then there is a slight kick of hoppiness at the finish.  It wasn¬ít what I was hoping for, but certainly not bad.

Very cloudy amber color with a big white head.  Aroma is strongly of orange peels with a light bit of clove and wheat.  Flavor has an orange peel-clove-hop-spice mix to it  with some wheat and banana in the background.  A bit odd, though its not bad.  I applaud the experiment, but this is way below the capabilities of both brewers.  Collaboration = good.  This beer = mediocre.
Cloudy amber with a nice big off white head.  Aroma notes of hops, cloves and banana.  Flavor to match with a bit of a dry hoppy finish.  Major thanks to vyvvy for the bottle.

Bottle. [Courtesy of nicolascage, session @ √òlbaren] Average to large thick white head that really lasted. Lovely hazy golden body. Thick film like lacework. Lars described that small peaces of hops could be found in the foam when they had the draught version. The sniff gave the impression of heavy sweet hoppy aroma, citrus, floral, hint of elderflower. Notes of coriander, banana and wheat could also be felt. Over the palate came underlying fruity notes and what appeared as pineapple. Full bodied with a thick texture and an average carbonation. Moderated sweet flavor with light bitterness and a hint of acidic. Extremely smooth and nice. Sweet and dry finish that ends light bitter. Wow that was amazing and apart from the Aventinus this was the second best Weizen Bock that I ever had! 18-09-2007, Thanks Lars and Kim!

500 ml bottle purchased at John¬ís Grocery in Iowa City. Poured an orange color with just a touch of haziness. Head was tall, bubbly, and white with good retention. There was only a bit of lace on the glass at the end. Rich aroma of banana, cereal grain, alcohol, citrus, clove, and a touch of caramel. Slightly sweet on the tongue with a strong clove flavor accented by banana and flowery hops. It also tasted a bit like smoked BBQ pork at times and there was an occasional grapefruity note at the end. Interesting.

RB #1600: 50 cL bottle, thanks to Lars and Kim for sharing especially this and many more beers on the 18th of September at √òlbaren. This poured hazy yellow to orange with a little white head. Very strong citrus fruity aroma. Very citrus fruity flavour, heavy heavy hoppy flavour. Most amazingly the finish gives a great caramel malty flavour which breaks the dominant hop-flavour. Fantastic.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2008 bottle....aroma: wheat. banana, and light on the spice with a nice citrusy touch (orange and lemon)......appearance: light to medium orange brown with fluffy slightly off white head....taste: smooth, slightly wheaty with emphasis on the weiss (banana and clove) with orange and lemon zest. just a touch of bitterness in the finish but mainly dominated by the weiss-ness.
Damn this was tasty.  Cloudy brown body with yellow hints and creamy head.  Hoppy banana nose with clove hints.  Yeasty body with plenty of hops and malt.

Bottle.
Hazy amber coloured with a white head.
Sweet aroma of bananas, caramel, hops and pine needles.
Flavour of bananas, caramel, hops and pine needles.
Hoppy finish.
The idea of making a hoppy weizen bock is quite good.

Bottle pours a thick cloudy brackish dirty orange with pillowy off white head. The aroma is right on the mark for the style. Its nice and big with sweetness, wheat, banana, tartness and hop spiciness. The taste is very similar with sweet sugary malts, hints of banana and spice along with a nice hoppy zest underneath. It leaves a pleasant taste behind. I¬íd love to have this on tap on a hot summer day. Excellent summer brew.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 This half liter bottle came as a nice surprise - how could I not try this collaboration between the Brooklyn Beer people and a leading German brewer?  There is a cloudy, golden color with a substantial head.  The fresh, sweet aroma has sour, yeasty notes.  Forthright flavor of wheat, hops, and lemon - bitter with a nice tingle on the fade out.  Now here is a robust brew that puts most stateside wheat beers to shame.

Hazy gold/amber and 3cm of frothy, white foam. Aroma of crisp, floral, lightly spicy hops, past ripe light fruits, wheaty grains, and a light dose of zesty yeast. Same flavors with more than a little candy like sweetness- too sweet, really the only minus, though. Dry, wheaty, yeasty finish. Medium/full body, foamy yet soft. Great brew.

bottle.  quite a nice collaboration between two great brewers.  pours a cloudy dark golden.  aromas of citrus and hops.  lots of sediment in this one.  nice overall palate.  very refreshing and full of flavor.  medium bitterness and pretty sweet.  nice thick head which turns into a white lacing.  I¬ím really glad I found this beer in my local store...

Bottle shared by Duff on 9/1/07Very, very heavily sedimented with hops.  It seems very gritty on the palate, which would seem to indicate hop pellets, but who knows.  The bitterness is certainly up there.  Almost like a Noble Hop dark wheat IPA.  There, I just categorized this one.  Not much head, possibly due to the hop oils, but the carbonation is fairly light too.  Deep, muddy, nearly opaque chocolate brown.I like the hops and I think they are well-done and fresh tasting/smelling, without any of the obnoxious C-hop bitterness (obviously), but the malt structure is a bit odd.  Chocolate and creamy base malt sugars don¬ít seem too assertive, nor is there any real cohesion between the malt and hops.  Yeast adds light banana and a hint of bubble gum on the finish, but is drowned out by hop bitterness.  Not sure what to make of this one, and while there¬ís nothing wrong with it (other than the fact that I think they could condition some more of the hop sediment out before bottling), I don¬ít think there¬ís anything terribly unique here.  Just a boatload of fresh hop flavor and aroma.

Well I must have shaken this one quite a bit as it is very opaque.  Bright aroma of the Saphir hops, a little banana, pear.  Dry with lots of dusty yeast character, a little alcohol, fresh melony hops.  Spritzy carbo.  More interesting than awesome.  Thanks Joe & Gabe!

Pours a brilliant golden orange.  The aroma is of a strong fruity hefeweizen but one can detect a hidden bitterness and the pungent strength of the alcohol.  The flavor is the same.  Traditional weizenbeer characteristics in harmony with a powerful dose of hop bitterness and alcohol.  An excellent beer everyone should try.

Quite a nice beer.  Very unusual with the intense hops and the wheat.  Great hop aroma with citrus and wild herbs.  Wheat in the flavor with some banana and lots of cloves as well as hops. A cloudy gold colored beer with lots of yeast and sediment.

Cloudy straw body with streaming jets and a clean sudsy white head.  Perfumy, nutty aroma with cooked banana and light caramel and wheat tones.  Flavor is nicely phenolic and numby with pleasant flowery esters.  Nice dryness and notable bitterness.  This is a very good, big pale bock.  Creative and vaguely in vein with Houblon Dobbelen.  That means I like it.

Murky amber/orange body with a large, fluffy beige head, lasting with sticky lace. The aroma is banana, citrus, cotton candy and herbal hops. The flavor is apricot, banana, herbs, cloves, spicy herbal hops and cotton candy. Medium body is very soft with moderate, but gentle carbonation and a sweet, peppery finish. My expectations weren¬ít high for this one coming in, but damn, this was a pleasant surprise.

Bottle, from Sam¬ís in Chicago. Pours with a thick, fluffy head, subsiding to a beautiful golden hue. Slightly sour nose, with lots of esthery notes. Starts a bit sharp, but finishes with lots of fruit and leather. Perfectly hopped with the noble Hallertau. Exceptionally quaffable, if one keeps the relatively high abv in mind.

Bouteille de 500 ml d√©gust√©e en compagnie de Dmac621, Dickinsonbeer, Cathschlag et Glouglouburp. Ar√¥me: Odeur de banane et d¬íagrumes avec une pointe d¬í√©pices. Apparence: La couleur est blonde ambr√©e voil√©e. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de banane et d¬í√©pices. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture l√©g√®rement min√©rale. Faible effervescence en bouche. L√©g√®re pr√©sence de banane en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #1233)

pours honeyish yellow large white head .yeasty citrus hops aroma  tastes (citrus) sour ? hopps bitter, sharp is a good word 
very interesting beer

Huge yellowish dense head, slowly collapsing over fully hazy orange beer. Bit sharp, phenolic nose; then dry hops, hopbales, faint sourish (wheat?), faint fusels. Intriguing. Sharp taste, again phenolic, touch of lactic & wheat acids. Hopflavour in the background. Slightly fruity, as a dusty muesli with dried unripe grapes and flaked grain; vaguely vinous. Much wheatslickness, well-bodied. Very interesting beer, great initiative. More tries might be helpful - then again, God forbid someone invents yet another "style"... Vielen dank, Sebastian!

Bottle. Pours a cloudy body with huge head. aroma is of banana, cloves, strong spices, slightly alcoholic. Flavor is all over the place. Rich in malt, yeast and a pretty dominant hop bite. A good beer but seems to be pretty rough.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2008 Bottle: Hazy deep honey-ish golden color with a substantial off-white head. This stuff is very aromatic. Tons of citrus-y hops. Has a bright lemon character, musty yeastiness, and a hint of coriander spiciness. Dense, lively carbonation which feels velvety. Has a great underlying tartness from the wheat malt, which makes it nice and sharp. Tons of citruses which lean toward orange/tangerine. Later flavors give off some spiciness, almost peppery (juniper) dryness. The alcohol is also well hidden. A very nice, hoppy Weizen Bock.

Spicy and bitter, sweet and fruity, grassy and lemony. A nice array of aromas and flavors. Attractive murky golden/yellow pour with huge slightly off-white pillowy head. Aromas of clove, apple, wheat, banana. Flavor is moderately sweet, slightly bitter and slightly acidic. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Alcohol warming in the finish. Overall, nicely balanced, refreshing.

another one acquired from ucusty...rich cloudy golden color with orange highlights.aromas...yeast, wheat,brown sugar, citrusy hops and an alcohol burn in the nose.  flavor profile is similar to the aroma with a bitter finish from the yeast and citric hops. a spiciness shines (alcohol or hops?) but is pleasant and refreshing. medium bodied with nice carbonation.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 500 ml bottle poured into my Paulaner Weisbier glass
The pour is a murky yellow/orange/brown with a billowing rocky white head.  Wonderful blend of banana and citrus.  Ass loads of hop flavor.  Nice bitter finish.  Spice and banana.  Pillowy mouth feel.  This beer kicks ass.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2010 In short: A fruity, sweet and hoppy wheat beer.  Hugely drinkable.
How: Bottle 500ml, consumed fresh a few days after purchase (side by side with sister Brooklyner-Schneider Hopfen-Weisse )
The look: Cloudy dark yellow body topped by a medium off-white head
In long: Nose of lemon pie and toasted wheat.  Taste has a lot of hay, flavours of crusty pie, banana cake and lemon.  A little sugary.  Strong spicy hops presence, with dry bitterness and white pepper sensation.  Some dry herbs. Nice acidic touch in the finish.  Little to no alcohol presence.  Body is a little fluffy.  Carbonation is very aggressive/tickling and it suits the beer just fine.  Feeling of a sweetened Berliner Weisse on steroids.  Side-by-side comparison I slightly preferred its american sister Brooklyner-Schneider Hopfen-Weisse.  A very good beer by itself but with its sister Brooklyner available this one becomes as essential as a screwdriver in an emergency operating room.

Pours a cloudy amber-orange with a large, frothy, off-white head. Wow. Sugary sweet and fruity hops on the nose, almost like candied hops. I¬ím just jazzed to sample a wheat with a solid hop presence. The floral hop character in this one reminds me of Two Hearted, only just a bit sweeter and with a faint wheat backing. Light to medium-bodied and slick with a nice, lightly bitter finish. The flavor is sweet candied hops, light mildly dry wheat with a bit of hop resin coming forward at the end. If there are any bubblegum, banana or clove characteristics in here, they¬íre well hidden behind the hops. As a fan of wheats and IPAs, this is an amazingly tasty and drinkable beer, especially given the ABV. If you¬íre a die-hard IPA drinker and don¬ít care for wheats, you might find it a bit thin for your tastes, but if you like wheats, and you¬íre a hop head, this may just be the beer for you. After sampling Gumballhead a while back, I¬íve been jonesing for another hoppy wheat, and now we actually have one that¬ís available locally. My hat is off to Mr. Drexler and Mr. Oliver.

Bottle: Pours a cloudy orange with a lot of head, looks to be well carbonated from all the bubbles, aroma is kinda grassy and fruity, flavor is hoppy and slightly bitter.  It¬ís an OK beer but problably something I won¬ít pick up again.
Draft.  Pretty decent eisbock.  Unusual flavoring which is really tough to desribe.  And wow the alcohol is camouflaged.

Bottle 500ml.  Pour is a dark muddy orange with some gold highlights.  The head pours huge and consists of tight foamy bubbles that reduce to huge bubbles.  Aroma is very familiar but I¬ím having a hard time putting my finger on it.   There is some banana and cloves but also a big sweetness. Enticing.  The flavor is even more interesting.  For a weizen bock this is incredibly complex.  The first thing I taste is some hops and the cloves, flowery.  Then the sweet candy bock rolls over my tongue and really bursts.  The finish is just enough clean enough not to be cloying.  Where are they hiding the alcohol?  The body isn¬ít overly weighty but it does have substantial mouth feel.  This is a true example of the wonders of collaboration.  Two fantastic brewers working together to combine the strengths of both into a truly exciting beet.  Job well done.

There are times when genius is spawned by merging disparate things, chocolate and peanut butter, oil and vinegar,
Salt and pepper.  But this ugly, skunky, bladder-infection looking hoppy mess is NOT one of them!
This is NOT a Weizen Bock...this is a double IPA mixed with a formerly good dark wheat.  
Looks, smells, and tastes bad.
Congratulations, Schneider, you finally made a beer I¬íd rather pour out.

Booming head, peculiar aroma. As the head fizzles upward, we¬íre looking at a dusty, polished gold beam and a tight, pillowy tan head. The aroma signals cherry blossoms, clover, anise, buttered lilacs and licorice root. A mild cedar gloss comes in with corn syrup on the backend. Flavor achieves a mildly chewy body, allocating buttered vanilla rum toffees all around. Soft white floral petals, cackled white pepper and clover concur the herbal spiced signature. Warming mouthfeel with didactic, dialed down carbonation, leaving an almond clover alcohol sting and flavor through the mouth post sip. Too many raw green hops emitting a palatary greenhouse effect. Green lemon grass stems twine with bleached honey and jojoba almond butter for a franticly white spiced ending chock full of anise and cackled clover.

Bottle from Capones sampled with Mad_indian. pours a funk hazy dirty water color with a foamy off-white head. Aroma of Banana, wheat spices, and hops. the flavor is moderately carbonated, banana, wheat spices, and traces of bitterness. Great brew, but not better than Aventinus.

I found this bottle in NYC at New Beer on Chrystie Street and after a slight chill, the ale  came though with a grapefruit/hops aroma that invited the first taste. With a smooth base of malt, hops roar like lions with bitterness and a slight maple syrup nuance that kept me interested. The rolling variety of tastes kept me from noticing the alcohol as I served the ale with broiled chicken and string beans steamed with garlic slices. This was a very good ale and I wondered how it tasted on tap.

500 ml bottle. Poured a hazy light orange/amber with a juge foamy white head. Started off with a great aroma of orange peel, wheat grass, hay, spice and other citrus notes. Flavor was a big let down with a very strong alcohol prescnece overall that really distracted from anything else. Mouthfeel was pleasant enough with a medium mouthfeel that had lively carbonation and a slightly dry alcoholic finish. Perhaps with some age to dull down the alcohol and this one might be a bit better but I have no idea how well this one will age.

Bottle.  Very sweet banana, peach, orange, pineapple and malt aroma.   Cloudy yellow-brown color with ample head.  Slight sweet (much less sweet than the aroma would lead you to expect) banana/pineapple, clove, and wheat malt followed by a moderate alcohol and mild astringent finish.   Very nice - strong Weizen characteristics which I really like.  Not quite as good as Aventinus but a nice solid beer.
Bottle from Capones, Sampled with Stegosaurus. Hazy dark orange pour with modest head. Banana wheaty aroma, a spice in the palate with a mild bitter sour taste. Balanced well. A good brew.

500ml bottle.  Aroma:  Banana, pepper and clove, pineapple, resin, wheat malt, yeast, lemons. herbal and earthy hop notes.  Wow.  Appearance:  Dark golden in color and very cloudy.  White head was huge and foamy/mousselike with great retention.  Great lacing.  Flavor:  Wheat malt and yeast, light breadiness, citrus, floral, and earthy hops, banana and clove, pineapple and bubble gum.  Some resin flavors come forward more as it warms.  Medium bitterness lingers for awhile.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium-high carbonation.  Overall:  This was better than I expected.  A beer packed with flavors that all seem to work together.  Surprisingly drinkable to boot.  Outstanding.

Poured a hazy yellow brown color with a large off-white head.  The aroma is lightly banana with a mild clove and light wheatyness.  The flavor has a wheaty citrus taste overall.  Some banana at the finish.  The alcohol is so hidden.  Great beer.

I love everything about this beer: I¬ím extremely partial to Wheat Beers, and there¬ís nobody who does them better than Schneider.  I love the cloudy, orange/gold color that reveals whisps of yeast that are gone as soon as they appear; the terrific head that could stand for hours; the citrusy aroma, and the sweet hop flavor that requires no lemon or orange to compliment this beer.  My only complaint about this beer is the price and how fast it disappears after I buy it.

Riddled, then pours a deep amber(chocolate and banana milkshake), multi-hued and extremely clouded, totally opaque. A white head, very tall and foamy/frothy, recedes slowly. The aroma is loaded with sweet esters, banana peel, boisterous pineapple juice and hefty clove. Grassy and green from start to finish, each inhalation cementing the new knowledge that this can indeed work. Cinnamon and nutmeg notes float into the prose that is this libation. There is a distinct appleskin note that pops out with each full draw. Light floral hops and earth round out this most interesting and unorthodox aroma. The flavor is moderately hoppy; I can¬ít imagine this being drinkable in many incarnations, but here it is blended well and yeast, wheat, hop and tropical fruit note interplay is well-executed and fun to unravel. bitterness is mild to moderate and extremely conducive to flavor and complexity expantion without drowning out low-profile wheat notes. Sweetness is medium and nowhere near cloying. Light, waxy white chocolate-wrapped caramels garner focus as the beer warms to room temperature. The finish is sweet and lightly peppered, yeast lingering, hop bitterness, grassy notes and clove beyond that; a finale is as complex as any other part of the experience. The mouthfeel is thick, smooth, lightly grainy with wheat malt, highly carbonated and well-dispersed across the palate. Knowing that this first batch is the only one that will ever be brewed at the German brewery that is partnered in this exploration is in itself rewarding enough. A chance to try a different interpretation, likely with some minor ingredient changes, will be reason enough to enjoy this again. Phenomenal.

Pours a bright gold until half way through the pour; then turns deep cloudy amber into a Weizen glass.  Fluffy off-white head with excellent retention leaves lacing as it slowly recedes.  Citrus and yeast aromas.  Cloves and cinammon upfront with a lasting citrus hop finish..

Cloudy orange color.  Smell of yeast, malt, lemons, bananas, clove, ginger and bread.  Taste the same but there is also alcohol and honey in the taste.  Alcohol is more noticable in the taste.  Refeshing.

Bottle. Quite estery and yeasty, and also very hoppy for the style. Earthy hop notes, touches of clove and banana, but with a definite slightly grassy, slightly green hop edge. Some floral notes. Palate is quite sweet and slightly thick and estery. Pretty good, and i¬ím sure many people will like this, but its just quite not there for me even though i did enjoy it.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2008 Pours a straw yellow/gold with a huge white head.  Smells of lots of fresh sage like hops, cloves, coriander, bubble gum, lemon, bananas, some hints of orange.  Tastes mildly bitter in a complimentary way with nice sugary undertones, and rich flavorful mint.  The best way to describe the taste is that it resembles a good hefeweizen someone decided to dry hop with some noble hops.  Mouthfeel is full and malty.  Finish is sweet and peppery with lots of spicey undertones.  The 8.2% alcohol is very well masked on this one.  I don¬ít usually go for ramped up versions of classic styles, but this in and of itself is a classic and you can definitely taste the influence of both brewers in this beer.  Excellent balance of hops and malt.  I hope more brewers attempt beers like this.

Pours a milky deep orange/golden with a large foamy/bubbly slightly off white lacing head.  Aroma of floral, orange and spicy hops.  Also getting some banana and clove esters.  Flavors of orange peel, tropical fruits, yeast spiciness, hints of earthiness, wheat malt, floral and chewy hops and again some of the banana/clove.  This one comes across as crisp, refreshing and dry with a great hop flavor while keeping hop bitterness in line.

bottle: pours a honey golden colour with a huge lively white head. aroma of spicey yeast, slight banana and juicy fruit gum, wheat malt and some lemon zest. pretty complex and very enjoyable. i have just smelled this for a good 7 minutes straight. flavour is spicey and yeasty upfront with wheat malts, clove and very small hints of banana. ends just a bit bitter and very enjoyable.

Bottle from John¬ís Grocery in Iowa City. Poured with a rich, hazy gold body. The head was massive and slightly off white. The aroma reminds me of a tropical mixed drink and is an interesting mix of banana and pineapple. There is also a hint of cinnamon. The taste is dominated by herbal character with lots of clove and cinnamon spice. There is also a mild note of canned peaches. The finish is soapy with raw hops. I wanted to like this beer and really looked forward to trying this one, however, I am not happy with the result. The European style noble hops failed for my tastes. This would have been better with more citrus tasting American hops. I still respect Schneider and Garrett Oliver, and I hope future collaborations are better than this one.
Bottle thanks to Adamskillin.  Beautiful aroma.  Super cloudy with white head.  Spectacular taste.  I recommend this to everyone.  Hops all ove combined with weiss flavors.  Excellent.
bottle from vintage cellars.  Cloudy yellow brown.  Sweet banana bread and clove aroma and taste with a hoppy finish.

Bottle, batch 1. Slightly lactic, kind of euro-hoppy nose. I take it back... VERY lactic. Big head on the pour. Slightly crisp, exotic fruit flavor, with a bit of passionfruit, mango... light hops in the finish, and wheat throughout. Slighty hot palate, not enough carbonation for the style. I appreciate the effort on this, and it¬ís nice to drink, but I don¬ít really like it much.

Bottle @ Spuyten Dyuvil.  Super cool bottle that hypridizes a german bottle with brooklyn¬ís logo.  Pours cloudy pale orange with a 1 finger off white head.  The nose is crisp hoppy and damn fresh.  The taste is amazing, it combo is really pretty unique, wheat yes, hoppy yes, and it works.  The palate is prickly on the tongue but smooth.  Nice
500ml bottle. Pours cloudy golden brown color with full foamy white head. Aroma and taste sweet, wheat and spicy with bitter finish.

Hazy orange with biggish white head.  Aroma is spicy with yeast and corriander, and smell s a bit cidery.  Taste is oddly fleeting, and cleanly departs the palate almost instantly, leaving only the faintest hint of hop and banana to ripple over the tongue.  $3/500ml   edit:  the brackish yeast layer on bottom makes it like drinking two different beers.  More bitter, more flavor... nice surprise.

Bottle: This looks like murcky cider with a ginormous fluffy head.  As the head slowly recedes, notes of wildflower honey, sweet pine, rose petals and spicey alcohol emerge.  The dryhopping adds a nice complexity to the style.  Very delicate, but loaded with dimension.  Very soft carbonation and lots of wheat create a lush mouthfeel.  The body is loaded with esthery fruits and creamy caramel malts.  Very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2009 Bottled: Aroma is fruity (plums), spicy, sweet malty and full of flowerly aroma hop. Very hazy, dark orange, light brownish color. Huge creamy head. Flavor is sweet, yeasty and pleasant fruity (apricot, plums). Notes of wheat and spices (pepper, cloves). Remarkable alcohol content. Long dry, bitter finish, herbal hops in the end. Very tasty weizenbock and a pleasant warming beer.  Many thanks to DerDoppelbock

At Capital Ale House - Downtown recovering from the heat after the Shockoe Craft Beer Festival 2007. Cloudy brown body with a medium frothy white head. sweet hoppy banana aroma. Sweet hoppy banana and light caramel flavor. Definitely a hopped up hefe, certainly an interesting and tasty creation.

Pours cloudy gold with a big head of larger bubbles. Aroma is floral/grassy hops which I was not at all expecting from this style along with the classic banana. Mouth feel is lively with a lot of carbonation. The flavor is unique with a mango like presence along with more hops than is normal for a Weizen Bock. Somehow it seems to work pretty well.  Thou I don¬ít think I¬íll be making this a regular, I¬ím glad to have tried it. 
Be sure to mix the yeast well, it makes all the difference in the world.

Bottle from west lakeview liqours in Chicago.  Cloudy orange with huge white head.  Aroma of lots citrus hops, sweet malt, some spice and yeast.  Flavor is citrus and pine hops, orange, some dough, caramel.  Creamy and med body which is the most weizen part of this beer, well that and the mild spices.  Overall a great collaboration with two distinct breweries.  As it warms it moves from IPA to Wit in complexity.  A strange example of when the beer warmed it actually lost most of the hop aroma.

Thanks to EDA and John for the bottles!  Poured slightly hazy medium golden with a towering cap of white head.  The aroma carried a hefty floral and perfumey hop presence, dusty, musty yeast, singed, rum-infused caramels, and a pinch of lemon.. full and intriguing.  Flavor had toasted caramel and wheat at the core with some sharper wheaty esters.. lemon zest accented the sides of the tongue leaving a dusty trail.. bit of overt alcohol showed up on the sweet finish.  Medium-bodied with a creamy middle paired with prickly wheat and hop bitterness.. left a sweet, but somewhat sharp finish.  This was good beer and an excellent idea.

A creamy, sticky white head settles over the beer, which pours a hazy, thick pureed old banana color.  The aroma is very banana and sweet hops. The taste is sucrose and banana with a slightly old, pungent hoppy finish.  Finishes with a cloying hoppy sweetness.  The beer seems very simple in the flavors it presents, but surprisingly the banana is not overwhelming nor is it as typically offensive as I find bananas in my beers.  This is good stuff, if a little too carbonated for me.
Edit:
As the beer warms, I get a resiny, piny hop bitterness that tastes like hop pellets in the finish.  Also, perhaps a little of an alcoholic taste too, if only because of the sharpness of hops.  There is a creamy banana/citrus (think dreamsicle) taste to the beer as it warms that is cut by those flavors.  I stick by my rating.  Very good, but not excellent.

Poured hazy yellow with fluffy white head. Aroma of fruit, spice, and hops. Kind of reminds me of a saison. Taste was totally different. Big bread flavor with some fruit hints.Very different and drinkable.
A unique variation of a tradtional style. I will definitely drink this agian!

Bottle.  Big big bready yeasty nose, tons of cloves and almost as much banana.  Lemon and a slight nutmeggy touch.  Cloudy dark yellow-brown pour with a large and full white head typical of the style.  Meaty and brawny.  Taste is a dark, dulling yeast with French bread and sourdough.  Full and a little crisp, rose petals with light citrus.  Touch of blood oranges and grapefruit, probably from the dry hopping.  Dry, dark, and a little murky on exit - I think the alcohol should be dialed down a bit, if possible.  A good Hefeweizen mixed with the high-alcohol catch-all that we call an American Strong Ale.  Not something I¬ím buying again (kinda messy), but a good go.

Pours a five+ finger white head that vanishes slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace.  Cloudy murky amber color, yeast in bottom of bottle.  Medium-strong carbonation and medium bodied.   Yeasty nose.  Flavor is yeasty, medicinal and herbal.  Lingering hoppy/tart aftertaste.  Different kind of wheat beer. Higher ABV is hidden.  $4.30 for a 500ml bottle from Tully¬ís Beer and Wine Wells, ME.
Fruity and citrus hop aroma. Cloudy orange color with a large lingering head. Fruity grape taste with a slight amount of hop bite finish.

Killer stuff here. Golden yellow pour with an large and fluffy white head. Big banana aroma with some clove and maybe cereal. The flavor is huge here. Lots of the aforementioned banana clove stuff going on with a fuckload of hops thrown in for good measure. Honey sweetness and a bit of cantaloupe as well. Well made beer that should sit alongside Aventinus and Aventinus Eisbock for all of eternity.

Bottle; poured a murky ruddy orange.  Large white head.  Aroma of wheat, lemon, spice, banana and yeast.  Nice soothing mouthfeel.  Flavor was subtle, tasty and good.  Banana, lemon, spice and caramel/toffee.  Some general fruitiness as well; possibly apple.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma is medium sweet.  Smells of floral hops, honey, pollen, blueberries, honeydew, and spices.  Poured brown in color with a large off-white head that lasted throughout.  Very small lacing.  Cloudy.  Opaque.  Lots of particles.  Very sparkling.  Looks like diarrhea.  Flavor is medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malts, toffee, caramel, honey, pollen, vanilla, resin, and Cheerie-Os.  Medium body.  Sticky texture.  Lively carbonation.  Bittersweet finish of caramel and pine.  Overall, I like this more than most other Weizen Bocks, probably because of the hops.  Complex all around.

500ml bottle. Huge off white head tops a murky golden brown body. It was only lightly hazed until the schmutz from the bottom of the bottle really clouded it up. Lemony wheat nose, a bit spicy. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Grassy flavors, lemongrass and grainy wheat. Some apple-like flavors. Interesting take on the style (one I don¬ít particularly care for) and well done.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 (500ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy brownish golden body with a huge long-lasting rocky beige head.  Aroma of florals, earthiness, and herbs.  Flavor of floral hops, banana, and cloves.  Very spicy Weizen Bock with a nice soft mouthfeel.

500ml. bottle. Cloudy yellow/orange color with a large white head. Very yeasty aroma, with lots of citrus, some banana, clove and an odd phenolic smell in the background. Flavor was again quite yeasty, with a lot of fruity esthers. Some banana and clove, with a bit of a floral aftertaste. Thankfully the odd phenolic aroma I got did not translate into the flavor.

This 500 ml brown bottle was labeled with an artwork that was a hybrid of the style of the two collaborating breweries.  I chose a ¬Ω liter Wezen glass to sample this beer, and the magnificent head on the pour that was contained in the glass made me glad that I did.  The body was standard pale, hazy, and bubbly Weiss beer affair, on second looks, may be a little thicker than normal. The aroma was so much more than the typical wheat beer smells of lemon, banana, bubblegum, and clove, due to the generous addition of noble hops.  The phenolic spiciness typically present in wheat beer taste was similarly enhanced here with the herbal hop addition.  In addition to the spices, I got a mouthful of tropical fruits like melon, pineapple, and banana,  The aftertaste was tart like lemon peel and granny smith apples.  Quite an authentic summer quencher, but watch out for that 8.2% ABV.  A bit fuller in the mouth than the norm, making it feel slightly green.  Otherwise just great the way it is.

500mL, no date from John¬ís Grocery.  Cloudy orange tea with a frothy 2 1/2 finger white head.  Lemon, pepper, and herbal hops are up front, followed by some yeast, spicy alcohol, and only slightly stronger than a hint of banana.  Lemony citrus and, pepper, and herbal hops again dominate the flavor.  Still not a lot of banana to be had, but I still get a fair amount of yeast.  Usually weizen bocks tend to be darker and heavier, but this, despite being fairly full bodied, is still refreshing due to the spiciness and citrus.  Dry earthy finish.  Moderate carbonation.  Glad I snagged a few of these.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: from sam¬ís chicago. this is by far the hazziest looking heffe i¬íve ever seem. this stuff is opaque. the last bit of this pour is a shit load of straight yeast. caramel color looks like dulce de lece with a fluffy white head. lots of banana and clove aroma. zesty, slightly spicy taste. lots of full grainy flavor with some bubblegum and a long satisfying finish.  terrific stuff.
Bottle at FFF,this was a hop up weisse that was very enjoyable and tasty,a smooth and enjoyable beer that i would like to get a hold of again.CHEERS!

Savannah, Ga. - Habersham Beverages - 500 ml bottle. Murky, dark orange pour with an elastic, sticky white head that sticks around for the whole bottle. Zesty, lemony aroma with hints of toffee, alcohol and bubblegum. Delicious, chewy, full-bodied flavor with hints of licorice, bananas, bubblegum, all blended together nicely. Chewy, sticky mouthfeel. Excellent example of the style.

Bottle from Spuyten Duyvil Grocery. Pours a cloudy gold into a nice, frothy, big-bubbled white pillow at the top. The aroma is deliciously yeasty, with traces of banana that catch up soon thereafter. First sip is punchy but smooth, with a powerful, fruity hop presence. Underneath all that is the undeniable wheat foundation, accented by citrus tang. It goes smoothly over the tongue with some mingling of spices, settling into a bitter, pleasant finish. Down the throat it¬ís cool but sharp¬óthe 8.2% alcohol doing its work. That might be a little too much of a presence, but this is a nice, full beer that¬ís easy to drink. Another fine effort from Mr. Oliver.

Bottle.   Pours cloudy straw color with a rather large pillowy off white head.   Aroma is grapefruit, floral hops, banana, yeast.   Flavor is hueg floral hops, pepper, wheat, citrus.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finishes bitter and refreshing.   Reminds me of Gumballhead.   I really enjoyed this beer, a nice surprise.

500ml bottle. Deutschland weizen glass. Cloudy yellow with a big head. Big banana aroma with some yeast. Hop bitterness and peppery notes dominate the first few sips and then you get some clove and lemon. As it warms you notice a bit of an alcohol bite and then a hint of grapefruit. The finish is quite dry and reminds me a bit of a saison. Another impressive brew by Schneider and Sohn.

Appears a densely cloudy dark golden bronze with a 3 finger head of off-white fluff that slowly fades away. Streams of CO2 quickly rise to the top upon first pouring this nectar before being phased out by the heavy amount of yeast that soon follows. Rich, spotty lacing is left all around the weizen glass. A real beauty to look at IMO¬Öif you can appreciate Bavarian wheats.
Smell is truly original in this one. Bananas, vanilla wafers, and clove greet you as always but wait¬Öit¬ís followed up with BIG, bold, ballsy amounts of citrus(lemon, grapefruit, orange), pineapple, and herbs. If anyone has wondered what a tour-de-force of estery yeast and juicy hops would turn out like¬Ölook no further. It¬ís here.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with an ultra high amount of zesty, herbal hops unlocking the door to the palate¬ís sensory threshold. 
Mouthfeel is smooth and velvety up front with a touch of sugary grapefruit easing down the back of the tongue for a nice, enjoyable, relaxing finish.
Ask yourself three vital questions before indulging in this beer. Are you a fan of Schneider Weisse beers? Are you a fan of hops being profiled in any beer style? Have you enjoyed any of the other Garrett Oliver projects, such as Blast? If so, this will be a pleasant surprise on all levels. If not, it will be an adventure for your taste buds that they most likely haven¬ít been through before. Personally, pour me another!

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 Courtesy of Styles
Bottle:    The aroma is yeasty with some banana and faint clove.  It pours a mostly transparent orange with a large white head that lasts a minute or so.  The flavor starts with a quick yeastiness and sweet banana.  The finish has moderate floral and grassy hops with some faint spice.  It¬ís medium bodied with soft carbonation.  7-4-7-4-14
Re-rate on 5/19/08:
Bottle:  Bottle:  The aroma is a nice combination of citrus hops, bananas, oranges, bubblegum, light clove, and faint floral notes.  It pours a very cloudy brownish-orange with lots of sediment and a large creamy white head with excellent retention.  It leaves behind thick rings/clumps of lacing.  The flavor starts with lots of banana and light bubblegum.  A big citrus hoppiness comes in the finish and really blends well with all the sweet banana and bubblegum.  There are some hints of pine and clove in the finish as well.  Moderate citrus hopped aftertaste.  Medium-full bodied with a soft mouthfeel.  A significant improvement the second time around.  I will definitely have be drinking more of this.

Bottle from the Good Beer Store. Poured a slightly hazy golden with a big fizzy white head that fades. I dont think this is a weizenbock. Its not dark and it really isn¬ít that wheaty, at least in the hefe-sense. Nose is bitter and hoppy with a slight sweet wheat aroma.  Flavor is a little muddled as frumpty put it so nicely, and alcohol is a little bit to noticeable.  The balance just seems off, but I appreciate the effort from these two fine brewers.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2008 Rerate: Assuming a new batch, with new label. This seems far less assertive and much less biting. I‚Äôm still getting the spices and fruits, but not all the alcohol and  pepper. 
  16 August 2007 (7,4,7,3,14 - 3.5) To be brutally honest, I am getting a bit tired of all these high gravity/alcohol brews. They are simply tiring me out. Murky bronze color with a tall heavy cream colored head. Hugh hoppy aroma, with herbal notes of rosemary and wintergreen; spices of mace and cloves and tropical fruits. Somewhat exotic scents, but not really my thing. Full, yet spritzy in feel. Light malt is quickly swept away by spices, and lot of them. Cloves, cinnamon, white pepper, allspice all make a rather abrupt appearance and continue though to the bitter end. Some grapefruit covered with vanilla noted in the finish along with a light return of pale malt. Finish is sharp and biting as the tongue is hop with a red pepper tingle. Perhaps just to assertive for my palate as of late. Perhaps this will mellow.

on tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. After finally being able to muster up a glass due to keg problems. Well worth the difficulties. Cloudy, murky gold. Eartly, slightly medicinal.slight banana. alchol not noticable. well done looking forward to bottle version

bottle from whole foods.  pours a characteristically heady cloudy off-gold.  aroma is bananas, esteres, and earthy hops, a glorious combination.  body is medium, with the wheat sweetness prevalent up front, fading into a beautiful hop flavor finish.  perfectly crafted.  easily one of my favorites of the year, and will be a perrenial favorite if they keep making it (fingers crossed)

Bottle.  Enjoyed this more than I expected.  Nice hazy gold pour...big white head.  Great spicy nose...flavor is a great yeasty, clovey, hoppy mix.  Strong for a session weizen, but I could get used to it.  Nice bitterness in the end....with a great spicy hop bite.

Got this on tap at My Place, Newtown, CT; beautiful wheat golden color; soft, fluffy white head; aroma of fresh sweet flowers, pleasant, not old lady perfume; flavors of hop and wheat, delightfully done...very nice summer beer.

Heavy 500 ml bottle. This is just fun. Pours a kind of IPA copperyness, but with a fluffy weizen head that leaves rings. Smell leaves behind the weizen esters for fresh, grassy hops. Is that what APA levels of Hallertau can yield? Fascinating. Taste seems pretty hot, but not just from alcohol. Nice and spicy, some pepper, and that itch in my mouth when I eat fresh cherries. Citrus and other fruits wander in and out of my palate. Has to be some dry hopping at work here. And the sweet malt just keeps pouring in. A real lip smacker. Found this at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/homewo Liquors, Homewood.

7/26/2007:  Schneider & Brooklyner Hopfen-Weisse looks like a beautiful German Hefe.  It is hazy/cloudy and deep gold in appearance with a massive beige head that stays throughout.  A spicy hop aroma is complemented with some Belgian-like fruity wheat malt.  The flavor is floral and spicy and has a growing alcoholic taste and sensation.  It finishes peppery and leaves a lingering spiciness and bitterness.  This beer is medium-bodied and quite smooth.  This is one solid German Weizen Bock created by two world-class breweries.
500 mL bottle (8.2% alc./vol. / 0001 2717 07.145) shared by Peanut at the Dilly Deli.  Thanks Tom!  Rating #90 for this beer...

Never would have pegged this as a wiezenbock, but no matter.  Pours a murky brown, frankly unattractive I¬ím sorry to say, with a decent head.  Aroma is a neat mix of floral and spicy hops with cloves from the yeast.  The flavor is similar, but with a bit of bubblegum mixed with aspirin bitterness on the end.  Neat experiment that I really liked, the bitterness was terrific.  Better than my numbers indicate.

Bottle, from Capone¬ís (Norristown, PA) Poured hazy, deep orange amber color capped with a big, frothy off-white head that extender above the top of the hefe glass. Strong banana aroma, with accents of orange peel, hops, and clove.  Wheat is initially the predominant flavor, but rapidly gives way to palate-coating hops. Long, dry, bitter finish. This beer is really unique and achieves a harmonious balance between the wheat and hops. I¬íll definitely buy it again.

500ml bottle.  What a great marriage of world-class brewers.  This had a mild eruption of foam, pouring an opaque muddy orange with a large boiled head.  The aroma is immensely spiced, full of esthers and earthiness.  From the first sip, I¬ím unfortunately a bit put off.  This presents itself gritty and dirty, with a big chewy hop conistency that doesn¬ít quite match the florally sweet, wheaty undertow.  I can appreciate the creativity and the artistry of some of the planet¬ís greatest brewers, but I can¬ít say I really care for it that much.(#3057, 8/13/2007)

(50cl bottle) Large off-white head atop murky amber body.  Aroma is medium sweet, lemongrass, spice, some clove, light bubblegum.  Taste is medium sweet, herbal/grassy, some apple, honey, alcohol, wheat, lemon.  Somewhat dry finish.  Medium-full body with some creaminess.  First dry-hopped weizenbock I¬íve tried, and while it¬ís dominated by characteristics other than what I expect in a weizenbock, it¬ís darned tasty however you want to label it.

Poured a murky, bronze color with a very large, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of vanilla cream, orange peel, citrus fruits, light skunk, grass, floral hops, clove, and pine.  Taste of vanilla, light honey, citrus, pineapple, banana, grass, some coconut, grapefruit, and a bitter hoppiness.  Dry alcohol in the finish.

Bottle from Capone¬ís.  Turbid dull copper color with 2-finger off-white head.  Aroma of citrus, hops, clove, florals, canteloupe, apricot.  Tastes dry, floral, spicy, with yeasty malt, canteloupe, some tart fruit, and clovey spice, all mixing together to make a very complex beer that retains a solid fruit, hopcitrus, floral, and spicy character throughout.  Well done.

Pours out a murky and opaque amber-brown color. Porduces a thick, tight and enduring white head. Thick sheets of foam adhere to glass as it empties. Tremendously complex aroma profile here; extremely unique. Assertive floral, perfume, banana, clove, orange, pineapple and Hallertauer hops spice notes fill the nose. Mouthfeel is full-bodied and fluffy; however the carbonation level is a bit flat for a Weisse beer style. Could use a tad more spritz. Luscious flavors of ripe banana, peach, bubblegum, mango, spices, fresh cut grass and vanilla greet the tongue. Taste seems a bit tamer than the aromas, but still a delicious treat. Finish reveals just a hint of hop bitterness and alcohol to add to this brew¬ís uniqueness. Although I¬ím not a huge hefeweisse fan this beer was well worth seeking out.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Smell is of hops and citrus notes, with a faint call to delightful Belgian yeast strains. Color is turd water brown, with large white head that slowly dissipates to half its original size. Spicy flavors resonate, with some banana, wheat, mango, and a pinch of chalk. Very drinkable, beyond what the 8.2% indicates. All-in-all, feels much more like a Belgian ale than a wheat beer.

Pours a large white haed, good retention with a fair amount of lace. Seriously merky, ugly gold brown color. Nose is spicey hops, citrus and yeast. Body is lightly medium, a little sticky on the palate. Sweet malts up front backed by citrusy hops and a faint breadyness. Grassy and green are the hops. Malts are buried under the hoppiness of this brew. Wheres the bananna, cloves, darkness, etc, etc??? Quite a strange marriage that does,nt really work at all. Finish is sweet and fruity. How this brew is even mentioned in the same category as Aventinus is unbelievable to me. Enjoy!
Weird, but good.  Very murky pour.  The aroma and flavor remind me of a big basket of mixed fruit and flowers.  Sweet hefe-like entry segues into a firm hop finish.

This is a funky looking beer - like apple cider, but someone has informed me that its because it includes the bottom of the barrel.  Lots of sweet, honey wheatiness in the aroma, even along with some apples, I think.  This is an interesting beer.  Very full-bodied for a wheat, and the alchol is very smoooth and well-hidden.  Chewy.

I¬íve waited far too long to try this beer - cloudy orange body that somehow seems to capture light and radiate it back outwards - a foamy head of loose bubbles settles quickly, leaving a soapy-looking lace, which itself eventually disappears - the aroma is an inviting mixture of orange, banana, wheat, light nuttiness, strong, earthy hops, and biscuity malt - begins with a mild orange sweetness, followed by a strong wheat malt flavor, along with some banana (actually more so than regular schneiderweisse) - the beer dries out quickly though, as a robust hop profile swells up just as this dry quality develops - this is followed still by some tangy citrus and mild yeasty notes - the flavor isn¬ít as great as the aroma suggests, but this is still a great beer.

VERY NICE HYBRID OF TRADITIONAL GERMAN SPICE AND BANANA FLAVORS AND THE GREAT TASTE OF AMERICAN VOLUME OF HOPS. REMINDS ME OF THE PENNENT ALE. THIS BREW IS A CLEAR WINNER -THOUGH IT DOESN¬íT LOOK LIKE MUCH IN THE GLASS. KIND OF MURKY AND YELLOWY GRAY. SO VERY HYBRID WITH THE CLASSIC GERMAN AND AMERICAN PROFILE OF -THEIR OWN STYLES OF BEER - DON¬íT ASK ME HOW IT WORKS I DON¬íT KNOW BUT GET YOU SOME AND EXPERIENCE IT. THAT IS IF YOU LIKE AMERICAN AND GERMAN BEER OR CAN APPRECIATE A WORK OF ART. THE WEAVING OF FLAVOR TEXTURE AND STYLE IS TRULY INSPIRING FOR ANYONE WHO APPRECIATES ANYTHING WELL DONE.

500ml Bottle
$3.99
Binny¬ís Orland

This is an interesting concept. A dry hopped weisse and it¬ís a Brooklyn collaboration I had to give this a try when I noticed it. Pours a beautiful glowing yeast induced hazy orange. Unfortuanately not much of a head formed which surprises me. Half finger at it¬ís largest and quickly fading to a thin skim. The body does look damn good though.

Strong orange aromas rise from the glass with a very noticeable wheat twang. A squeeze or two of grapefruit pulp, which I¬ím guessing comes from the "robust" dry-hopping. Mild clove in the background and a slight medicinal sweetness. The aroma is very unique and very mouthwatering.

Wow. The flavor just doesn¬ít stand up to the wonderful aroma. Very subdued flavors that mesh well together but just don¬ít really stand out like I hoped. Grapefruit and orange are the dominant flavors but it¬ís hard to tell where one begins and the other ends. Does have a nice fresh floral/grassy hoppiness to it. Again, hard to pick the difference. Flavor is good but a little too muddled and hard to define.

Thin mouthfeel with sluggish carbonation. It¬ís odd but with the thin mouthfeel it still leaves some residue after the swallow. In my opinion this beer needs a little more creaminess. It seems a little too watery. Higher carbonation wouldn¬ít hurt either.

Easy drinker for the high abv but with the muddled flavors and thin mouthfeel one pint is enough.

This is no doubt a good beer with an excellent aroma but (and I¬ím not a brewmaster such as the two who got together to brew this so take this with a grain of salt) to me this beer could use a little tweaking and it could be a great treat. I probably would buy again cause it is enjoyable and unique but like I said, one at a time is enough for me.

8/11/07

This is an interesting and tasty beer.  Looks like a German wheat, a hazy dirty yellow with a huge fizzy, sustained head.  The aroma has plenty of sweet malt, lemon, bananas, clove, and a flowery bitterness.  Well carbonated but medium bodied, it has the expected flavors of old bananas, bubblegum, clove, a twist of lemon, but also carries a light floral/grassy bitterness.  Quite refreshing, especially in this Summer¬ís weather, making me wish it was a year round brew rather than a special.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Downers Grove, IL<font size=-1>

Smells of lemons, and has a decent hop aroma. A nice gum aroma as well. A pleasing smell hits my nose. An odd color I must say. It has a tint of black mixed with orange. Decent looking beer, but I am not used to this apperance. Has a decent citrus hefe flavor, but in the aftertaste it tasted as though I was consuming Pine-sol. Not a bad flavor, just a weird one. Not my favorite type of beer, but a smooth texture. I am trying to pick out all the flavors, but it is hard because this beer has a unique flavor. Very malty, and somewhat decent. An okay brew.

This was a fair version of a German wheat beer.Pours cloudy orange color with lots of carbonation.Definately didn¬ít taste German to me.Lots of wheat and hop on th enose and the flavor had more of a hop presence.the finish was slightly hoppy and bitter.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 I¬íve been anticipating this for a while as i am a hophead and recently on a hefe kick.  slow pour yields about 3 finger white head.   cloudy copper/dark gold body.  Aroma is big lemon citrus and grassiness.  Body is not overly carbonated which is a surprise.  flavor: all over the place.  lots of lemon, some minty flavor in the middle, and clove spice on the finish.  medium bitterness.   aftertaste is bitter, pine and grass.  alcohol well hidden.  not sure they need 8% to make this interesting.  a delicious experiment that defies categorization.  they definitely picked the right hops to blend well with the wheat, unlike turbo hoppedamerican wheats (gumballhead) that are more ipa¬ís than wheats.  kind of tastes like allagash triple.  rerate second bottle.  the sourness and lemon is almost overwhelming.

Excellent weiss bier.    Still holds on to some estery, bubble gum aromas.  Esters are evident in the flavor and well balanced with the graininess of wheat.  Soft bitterness.   Clove, while assertive, is not overwhelming or out of balance like many imported versions.  A bit dark, could be brighter, but otherwise looks great in the glass.  Huge fluffy head, tiny bubbles; forms a nice lace too.

A very good example considering its journey to my glass here in the Midwest.

I had low expectations and am pleasantly surprised by this bad boy.  Nice big hop aroma I can smell from across the room.  Slightly spicy aroma as well.  Flavors of bread and wheat.  NIce malt back bone.  Color is a cloudy muted orange color.  Nice collaboration by these two guys.  You definitely get the influences of both in this beer.

The pour is actually a very unappealing cloudy greenish-brown colour that almost looks like an aftermath of a bad lavatory incident. The head is your typical abundant fluffy, velvety head that you get from just about every Hefe-Weisse. The aroma is very bread-y with strong floral hints. The taste is quite interesting. It¬ís definitely not your normal wheat beer. The hops is a more dominant in this beer. It¬ís like a spiced bread. The spices would obviously be the more dominant flavours since bread is pretty subtle. I do taste some very, very subtle notes of citrusy fruits. But the subtle flavours are difficult to define through the intensity of the hops. As the beer warms, the sweeter flavours tend to burst a little more. It seems to become a little more caramel-y. I can taste some banana as well. This is like a very americanized version of a german style... dump some hops into it! I like it. It¬ís different. I don¬ít enjoy it as I would enjoy the usual wheat beers, but it¬ís quite unique.

Cloudy gold color with a thick head.  Nice sweet, wheat, honey and banana aroma.  Fairly strong hop bitterness in the flavor (though Noble hops for sure).  The wheat is certainly there, but takes a back seat to the yeast and the hops.  Very good and tasty.
Biiiiiiiiittter!  Way frickin¬í bitter.  Sucks balls.  Barely a wheat.  Not a bock.  More of an american wheat and massively fizzy.  Metallic.  Avoid.

16.9 oz bottle.  Foggy orange brown with a big bubbled white head.  Wheat, orange peel and coriander.  Quenching carb with lime tang.  Wheat and banana make a brief appearance.  Final pour clouds things up but adds body and flavor.  Bitter grass and hoppy finish.  Aggressive for a Weizen Bock.

Draught at Capital Ale House downtown. Hazy, muted copper/straw color. Wheaty, spicy aroma, hints of fruit, bananas. Palate is medium, perfectly carbonated. Initial flavor is malty with a bitter hop crispness which gives way to complex wheat character. Hops are not subdued but not overdone. This is well balanced with notes of clove and honey.

bottle from keg liquors. slightly hazy golden with a big lasting great off white fluffy head. well blended floral banana clove aroma with light hints of caramel. balanced bittersweet banana clove flavor with an extremely floral backdrop with a touch of caramel. floral bittersweet medium dry spicy banana clove finish. medium body. lively carbonation. i found the beer quite balanced. nice interesting blend of wheat beer and floral hops. i really like the way the hops and the clove play off each other. well done.

500 ml bottle served into a large Kapuziner weissbier glass produces a murky amber body and an immense offwhite head. Second pour with the yeast swirled in results in a dirty mustard body. Head becomes pitted and rocky. Aroma of clove and fresh oranges followed by an onslaught of IPA type hops that offer up pine and grapefruit notes. Taste is like a mix of a Hefe and IPA. Citrusy grapefruit lords over the faint banana and wheat notes. Clove and white pepper notes add a nice spicy element. Finishes with a bitter grapefruit rind bitterness like an IPA. Interesting effort from two great breweries but I don¬ít personally care a great deal about such a hopped up Hefe.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2007 Bottle. Opens with a pleasant nose of bananas, cloves, white pepper and German hops. A good amount of dry hops, yeast and wheat on the palate. Nice balance between sweet and hoppy dryness. A worthy effort, for sure.

This was really enjoyable.  Beautiful head and body.  I thought the hops were wonderful, but they seemed to overpower the better aspects of the weizen side of things.  That is, the hops interfered with the clove or banana yeastiness, and kept the beer from acheiving the full measure of its promise.  I see, however, that few share this view.  Notwithstanding all that, the rich malt base worked really well with the hops and the result was still excellent.

Bottle from State Line liqours, Elkton, MD. My wife asked me why it had a muddy look and I sipped. It had a powerful banana citrus-esque blast with some peppery bitter hops and a heavy yeast character. I enjoyed it but am not sure where this falls on the drinkability scale because it seems a bit too sweet and fruity. I love hefes but there is a bit too much of a cloying element which could be the coriander at work. I would still say this is well crafted given these flavors.

Bottle... Cloudy golden ale with a huge, fluffy white head. Incredible retention. Yeasty, earthy aroma with heaps of esters and phenols such as soap, wet leather, pale grains, clove, soft campfire smoke and black pepper. The flavor is spicy and beefy and bows toward the bitter side of balance with alcohol and a hoppiness that really puts the clamps to my palate. Pale grains lend support underneath it all. Medium to full-bodied and astringent as Hell with lively carbonation. Spicy, Mojave-dry finish. Kudos to boboski for giving me this bottle!

Pours a murky dark bronze after adding a healthy swirl of the yeast from the bottom of the bottle.  Head is off-white, airy, about an inch high, and has some spotty lacing.  Aroma of floral, earthy, spicy noble hops and some sweet wheat with a touch of bready German yeast.  Starts with a fairly full body, good carbonation and sweet malted wheat giving way to a big, fresh, perfumy hop bitterness with some notes of pine resin and warmth toward a bittersweet finish.  A very unique hop character that seems to be well-balanced with the malty sweetness.  Enjoyable fresh, but I¬ím guessing this will probably age well too.

like other schneider beers lots of carbonation great big white head, beer itself was a weird brown mud color, had a citrusy smell and nice sweet taste, definately something different here but its for the better.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2008 Bottle into a weizen. Pours a very, very cloudy golden hue with a tall, well developed white head. This stuff smells awesome. My good friend is a homebrewer and for his latest batch he decided to brew a German styled hefeweizen with American styled hopping. Well, looks like someone stole his idea (okay, maybe it¬ís been done before, but I¬íve never had one.). The good news is that it is evidently awesome. The aroma has generous, defined citrus notes and bright, herbal spiciness. I get a little bit of the banana and wheat too. The flavor doesn¬ít quite live up, but it is very drinkable. Less defined, potent hops are present on the palate but it still packs quite a punch for this style. Moderate banana sweetness and cloves intertwine with hints of grass, pepper, pine, lemon.  Actually, as weird as this is, it¬ís pretty tasteful. I see that these are Bavarian hops, but they a rather PNW attitude in this particular brew. The finish hints a little at bubblegum and is semi-sweet, drying out the palate only slightly from the heavy use of Hallertauer.  I personally am a fan of American styled experimentation in beer, it worked very well in this case. I was wooed by the individuality of this one.


[March 10, 2008]


Picked up another bottle of this stuff since I loved it so much the first time around. It has held up well for the last few months, but is nothing like a fresh bottle. The aroma is mildly spicy but is lacking the fresh citrus/pine thing. Still hints of juicy pineapple, banana, and cloves shine through with clarity. The flavor is less aggressive as well, but still packs a decent citrus presence and is moderately dry. Side note: when I poured the last bit out with all the yeast, the liquid was olive green. Pretty neat. 

[July 7, 2008]

Bottle best before January 7, 2009. Pours very cloudy drark gold with a huge white head and rather large floating particles. The aroma is delightfully spicy with citrus, rough wheat, lemon, banana, clove, it seems very juicy. mm. The mouthfeel is just spritzy enough. I really like this beer. The hop quality is not obnoxious by west coast U.S. standards, but it is hugely assertive for the style. Lots of biting, spicy citrus and wood, slightly wild esters, perfectly balanced bread/wheat/fruit sweetness, and rich lemon are all noted. This stuff is fantastic. I seem to remember my first encounter being hoppier, but I‚Äôm thoroughly enjoying this bottle. I‚Äôd feel guilty for lowering the score. Delightful for the summer.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2008 Pours lightly hazy and golden with a fluffy tan head. My first bottles of this were very turbid, recent bottles have cleared up. Aroma is thick and sticky with fresh hops. Notes of Hallertau orange juice, and spicy notes of lemon, herbs and pepper. Taste is lightly sweet, with more hop juice, this time with a little balance from the yeasty esters. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, and slightly sticky with lush carbonation. I really like Schneider, but I¬ím not a fan of using noble hops like this.

Rating #1: Ar6 Ap3 Ta7 Mf4 Ov14
Rating #2: Ar7 Ap4 Ta7 Mf4 Ov15

Very cloudy orange/brown, with a huge head. Tons of yeast. Nose is grassy, slightly soapy, with some banana notes. Quite a bit of lemony tartness hits the tongue first, giving way powerful hop flavors--bitter, with some fresh cut grass. Perhaps too bitter, really. A very earthy quality underneath, and some sweetness--hints of the banana and bubblegum expected from a weizen, but not really enough residual sweetness to stand up to that hop blast.

Bottle. This comes with a LOT of hype. I was very eager to try this. The pour erupted with lots of foam, which is typical for a hefeweizen. Tall sturdy light tan head. Murky gold-to-amber colored body. Aroma is spicy with floral hops, lots of fruit (grapefruit, lemon peel, soft banana and pear juice), soft wheat and yeast. Taste is hoppy and different. Lots of citrus fruit, subtle yeast notes, banana, grass, flowers, spices, light bready notes and bitter hops. Body is light and crisp. Very bubbly. The burping begins after only a few sips. More lively carbonation expands the hops, fruit flavors, and yeast into a mildly satisfying finish. Citrusy hops and fruits intermingling with fading hefeweizen flavors. Like an IPA cut with hefeweizen to reduce the hop bitterness for someone not liking IPAs. Don¬ít get wrong I like this and appreciate the experiment, but I would have liked more of the hefeweizen to come through.  ***Notching the appearance up due to all of the sediment coming out at the end. Added a nice rocky head and some interesting yeast swirls throughout the body.

Bottle at Dilly Deli. Poured an hazy dark orange color with an large fizzy white head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Heavy sour citrus, banana and clove and alcohol aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Heavy balanced bittersweet flavor with a medium spicy bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer.
Bottle. Nose is citrus and hop resin with lots of spice. Clear golden with a great white head. Well balanced hops without much wheat character. Really nice and drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2010 500ml bottle. poured everything into a FFF imperial pint glass. with the sediment it created this very muddy awful looking greenish-brown with white head. the worst looking beer ever. if i could do it over i¬íd just pour some of the yeast in there. but i think i did pour correctly to style but what ever. nose is very zesty, peppery, orange peel. flavor is crisp sweet, biscuit, peppery hops, citrus, toffee malt finish. pretty nice.3.5. 

5/15/08, 2008 vintage. pouring this without the yeast looks better a 4 but with it, although not nearly as bad as my initial review, a bit dull. it does however taste better with the yeast. the finish has more depth and handles the bitterness better. really tasty brew. and very similar to NG Imperial Weizen. Both equally great. 3.9
From tap poured hazy golden with lots of head.  Nice hefe flavor with a solid finish.

Pours a cloudy orange with a big, fluffy, white head.  Citrusy aroma, dotted with cloves and spices.  It starts out like a normal weiss, but the finish is quite hoppy. Keeping it simple, it¬ís quite an interesting brew.

Bottle from Sam¬ís Downers Grove. What a find! I¬ím glad I noticed the distintive Brooklyn Brewing "B" on the label on the German beer shelf at Sam¬ís. Smells like a melding of brewers from Germany and the U.S. There¬ís the wheat aspect as well as a discernable sweet aleish hop aspect. Hops and wheat. What a concept! Poured into a weissbier glass, pours a beautifully murky brownish orange with a huge, overflowing foamy head. I can count on one hand the number of American brewers who have been able to create the big, billowy head that seemingly all the best German weissbier brewers routinely produce. Clearly Schneider¬ís expertise comes through in a tangible way. High alcohol and hops are the initial impression. Clearly displays the American influence. Peppery. Excellent. My only regret, and it¬ís a small one, is that this wasn¬ít a little lower in alcohol which would make it as drinkable in session quantities in the summer as a great German weissbier. Nevertheless, I¬ím guessing Oliver thought of that, but wouldn¬ít have been able to adequately showcase the hops in a lower gravity brew. One of the better US-German collaborations since the end of the Cold War.

Bottle and served in ye olde standard hefeweizen glass: Thanks to my skills has a master decanter, I got a nice run of the remaining yeast out of this baby so it is nicely murky and deep amber with a lasting frothy off-white head and most excellent gnarly lace. Now I knew in advance that this would be a hopped up weizen but boy oh boy my nostrils still got smacked down with the massive herbal and citric hop attack. Yeah there be some wheat and yeasty vapours here too but you really gotta work at finding them.  The taste is a perfect match with the aroma with a lot of hop characteristics up front and personal. Damn it Garrett, back away for the hop bag and no one gets hurt! Man I could taste the grapefruity and blood orange notes foe a hour afterwards. Biggie would be proud. Oh back on track, once again you gotta work at finding the weizen yeast strain notes but in due time they will come about upon the finish.  The mouth feel is strange due to the metallic overtones and the yeasty chalky tour de force. Okay folks and other assorted beer animals, this is not your great great grandpa¬ís old skool Hefeweizen. Despite all the new world flava flav, I really found this is like the FLYAGRA  of the beer world. Werd to ya grandpa-pa.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 Thanks Biercraft in Park Slope, Brooklyn - 08/01/07.  Medium gold with a tall loose white head.  Loads of fresh juicy hops in the nose with bright orange and lemon citrus, fresh grass, and pine needles alongside wheat malt and some Bavarian hefeweizen fermentation characteristics.  The flavor is first and foremost hoppy with fresh oranges--though distinctly different than West Coast American hops citrus characteristics--and lush yellow tropical fruits.  This is the finest, most intense, and purest expression of Hallertauer I have ever experienced--so fresh, so bright.  All of this is backed-up by a foundation of wheat malt flavors that totally hide its alcohol--this is muscled finesse.  So unusual.  So good!  Finally a classic European brewery has adopted an American philosophy of hops with wild success.  This is a significant breakthrough.
2nd Tasting - 10/24/07.  The fresh hops have faded a bit and are more integrated into the wheat malt and alcohol flavors--though still contains plenty of lemon and grassiness.  The bitterness remains crisp, clean, and refreshing with some spice in the finish.

Yeasty aroma in my face. I would argue that this is another "turned up to 11" beer, but this one has plenty of distortion. Took me a long time to get past a hop that I might like with other beers, but find a tad medicinal with a weiss (imperial weiss?). After some time I did warm to this more and more. Think my favorite aspect was getting this in trade with mj (Thanks Mike!)

Thanks to Solan for the knowledge. This pours out hazy weiss and two toned (darker  on top and lighter on bottom) with a big off white head that has crazy fluffy lacing. Insane hop aroma for a wiess.  Wheat and citrus taste with a nice bang of hops. This is a wild collaboration of taste. A must try.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2007 pours a nice hazy copper with three finger head, and nice lacing.  grapefruit and hop aroma. very well balanced and complex.  fruits, hops and wheat for flavor. finishes with a kick of alcohol. excellent effort from schneider& brooklyn.

poured into schneider brooklyner weizen.  really excited about this.  what a cool glass it has.  pours a cloudy brown amber with full white fluffy head.  pours right perfectly to the line on the glass.  yeastie wheat, fresh mouthwatering, inviting aroma with some spiciness behind it.  initial strong warmth from alchohol offering a wheaty sweet background, to aftertaste, wheat really hits in the middle.  excellent complexity in this,  good palate, sweet buttery full mouthfull, and the aftertaste leaves your mouthwatering.  great beer but a little too strong on the alchohol presence.  not the style to age, but I may sit one for six months to see if it mellows.  this is not a sessionable hefeweizen but a great one at that.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2007 Cloudy dark orange in color with gigantic head on the pour. This head was so thick and huge, the top dried and formed a roof over the top of the beer. It later diminished and left a thin lacing. Aroma was great, citric and floral. Flavor was excellent, typical fruity wheat flavors with nice malts, light hops and a little spicy. Complex and delicious. Slight alcohol tingle was nice and not too harsh.

.5L bottle.  Pours a super hazy deep murky gold, almost a dull yellowish brown with a nice fluffy white head, good lace and nice retention.  Aroma is plasticy phenols mixed with some alcohol- too much wierd esters going on- almost solvent-like.  Grassy and a bit of cabbage aroma as well with hints of vanilla and clove phenols, and wierd garlicy off hop character- not really pleasant but not horrible.
